item.title: Paramount Is Officially Making A Call of Duty Movie
item.content:encoded:
Paramount has officially acquired the rights to produce a Call of Duty movie. In an announcement on Tuesday, it was said that Paramount will create a live-action film based on the long-running franchise.

The news comes just days after initial rumors began to circulate.

Paramount CEO David Ellison said that, as a “lifelong fan” of Call of Duty, the opportunity for his company to develop a movie on the franchise is a “dream come true”.

“Being entrusted by Activision and players worldwide to bring this extraordinary storytelling universe to the big screen is both an honor and a responsibility that we don’t take lightly,” he said. “We’re approaching this film with the same disciplined, uncompromising commitment to excellence that guided our work on Top Gun: Maverick, ensuring it meets the exceptionally high standards this franchise and its fans deserve.”

Ellison added that he can “promise” that Paramount will be “resolute in our mission to deliver a cinematic experience that honors the legacy of this one-in-a-million brand.”

Activision President Rob Kostic said that, with Paramount, the studio has found what he believes to be a “fantastic partner” to bring the series to the big screen.

“The film will honor and expand upon what has made this franchise great in the first place, and we cannot wait to get started,” Kostic said. “Our shared goal is quite simple — to create an unforgettable blockbuster movie experience that our community loves, and one that also excites and inspires new fans of the franchise.”

As far as who’ll write, direct, and star in the film, that information won’t be revealed for some time. Even a release date is far too off to be announced at this time.

The deal, according to sources at Variety, is for just one movie. However, there are opportunities to expand further.

What do you think of a Call of Duty movie being official? Let us know down below, and take the discussion further in the Insider Gaming forums.

For more Insider Gaming, check out all of the achievements you can earn in Borderlands 4. And don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Rockstar Has Delisted Red Dead Redemption 2’s Companion App
item.content:encoded:
Players searching for the Red Dead Redemption 2 companion app on Google Play Store or Apple App Store will find that Rockstar has delisted the application.

Red Dead Redemption fans are being greeted with multiple unfortunate updates today. Firstly, the actor for Rains Fall, Graham Greene, passed away at the age of 73. We have now learned that the companion application for RDR2 has been removed after being available for seven years.

Red Dead Redemption 2’s Companion App is No Longer Available for New Users

As revealed through Rockstar Games’ support page (via GameRant), the Red Dead Redemption 2 Companion App is no longer being offered on the Apple App Store and Google Play Store since August 19, 2025. Those who had previously downloaded the application will be able to access it through either their Apple or Google account’s purchase history. Moreover, players who purchased the Red Dead Redemption 2: The Complete Official Guide within the app will be able to access it there.

The Red Dead Redemption 2 companion app was released in 2018. It connected directly to the platform you were playing on and provided real-time interactive information on your smart device. Players could pan and zoom on the map, set waypoints, and mark areas of interest. They were also able to access Arthur Morgan’s core info and stats in real-time. Arthur’s in-game journal, stat tracking through Social Club, a complete digital game manual, plus an optional digital version of the Red Dead Redemption 2 Complete Official Guide from Piggyback, and more were available through the app.

In other news, the Red Dead Redemption 2 actor has admitted to misleading fans with an ‘exciting news’ comment. Additionally, a recent report has suggested that RDR2 could launch on Switch 2 this year. What are your thoughts on Rockstar delisting Red Dead Redemption 2’s companion app? Let us know through the official Insider Gaming forums discussion.

For more information from Insider Gaming, read about Borderlands developers revealing how their iconic art style was created. Don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Wordle Archive: Every Past Wordle Answer
item.content:encoded:
If you’re like millions of others who love Wordle, you known the thrill and, sometimes, frustration of trying to guess the daily five-letter word in six or fewer tries. What’s worse is when you accidentally miss a day, seeing your 99-day streak go out the window. But don’t worry, missing a day won’t take you out of the game. Our Wordle answer archive is here to help, letting you find every past answer, track trends, and spot patterns whenever you want. With every solution organized by year and date, catching up has never been easier.

Need help with just today’s puzzle? Visit Today’s Wordle page for hints, tips, and the answer to today’s Wordle.

How to Use This Archive

This Wordle answer archive is made to be straight forward for you, and is organized by year and month. Scroll to the month you’re interested in, or use your browser’s search feature to quickly find a specific Wordle number or date. Should you ever want to return to the top of this page, just click the “Return to Top” link next to a given year to be brought back to this section.

If you want to go to a specific year, click one of the years below:

  • 2025
  • 2024
  • 2023
  • 2022
  • 2021

Past Wordle Answers By Month And Year

There are over four years of words and answers for Wordle, and that means it can get overwhelming to find the answers you want. To help you, we’ve organized every answer—going all the way back to June 2021. To get started with the archive, open the dropdown for the month and year of the Wordle answers you’re looking for.

item.title: Borderlands Devs Reveal How the Iconic Art Style Was Created
item.content:encoded:
During a new interview, Gearbox CEO revealed how Borderlands’ iconic comic-book-inspired art style came to be.

With only 10 days left until Borderlands 4’s release, players have started learning new tidbits of information. Most recently, the complete list of trophies and achievements for the game surfaced online. Now, the developers have revealed how they zeroed in on the game’s beloved art style.

Borderlands Devs Started Working on a New Art Style Right Before the Alpha Milestone

In a conversation with GameInformer, Gearbox CEO Randy Pitchford discussed how Borderlands’ art style was developed and the numerous hurdles they had to overcome to achieve it. When development began for the original game in 2005, the devs were working on six different art styles, which varied from safe to over-the-top.

At the start, they felt that “it’s kind of got to be realism or there’s just no market opportunity.” However, it “just wasn’t exactly right for what the look and feel and vibe of what Borderlands was supposed to be – it didn’t match the gameplay.” Adam May, the art director for Borderlands 4 and a character modeler for the original game, revealed that when Fallout 3 was released, the developers realised that they were in the “same visual place” as Bethesda’s title.

Random Doodles Led to the Creation of Borderlands’ Beloved Art Style

At that time, May was sitting next to a concept artist for the original game, Scott Kester, who used to doodle “illustrated graffiti” during their free time. One of the characters created in these doodles eventually evolved into Captain Flynt, marking the birth of the iconic Borderlands art style that players know and love. With the help of Kester and executive producer Brian Martel, May transformed these 2D sketches into 3D game art and then pitched to Pitchford.

It was a sticky time for them as the game was on tight deadlines and was about to reach its alpha milestone. At that time, they pitched the idea of working on a brand new art style for Borderlands, and Pitchford miraculously agreed to give them two weeks to work on it. The CEO immediately regretted the decision, as he felt that the idea these guys were working on would have to be rejected, given the time constraints.

After the two weeks had passed, Pitchford entered the room, afraid of the inevitability, but to his surprise, the art team had worked wonders. As soon as he laid eyes on the new art style, he felt “it’s f—ing right; It’s right”. “It feels right. And it’s like everything we knew about what was wrong was confirmed when we felt it was right.”

Going Back to the Drawing Board

As soon as the new style was finalized, Pitchford knew it would take considerable effort to get it approved by 2K. Surprisingly, after the bit of back and forth, they agreed, and then most of the stuff had to be redone from scratch. The game was in development for several years at that point, and changing the art style meant leaving almost all the levels and characters behind. Only Trash Coast and one other level remained, and the rest was rebuilt.

In other news, check out Borderlands 4’s roadmap, which highlights all the future content for the game. Additionally, here’s Insider Gaming’s exclusive interview with Randy Pitchford. What are your thoughts on how Borderlands’ iconic art style was created? Let us know through the official Insider Gaming forums discussion.

For more information from Insider Gaming, read about Hollow Knight: Silksong developers offering free Switch 2 upgrade packs to Switch 1 users. Don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Does Borderlands 4 Have Crossplay? Split-Screen Status Explained
item.content:encoded:
The Borderlands franchise has always prided itself on its multiplayer and inclusivity. The games are still wild rides if you play them by yourself, but let’s see if Borderlands 4 maintains its co-op, split-screen, and crossplay focus for the newest sequel.

I think Gearbox is very excited about Borderlands 4. Not only did Randy Pitchford bring the game’s release date forward (an unheard-of move), but we raved about it on our exclusive preview, and Randy thinks it can break 100 million units!

If you’re excited about Borderlands 4 and want to know if you can play with friends across different platforms, you’ve come to the right place.

Is There Crossplay in Borderlands 4?

Borderlands 4 has complete crossplay functionality across every platform the game is launching on.

You can buy Borderlands 4 on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, PC, and Nintendo Switch 2. Pretty much every major multi-platform market box is ticked off for this one. It’s great to see the Nintendo Switch 2 getting involved in third-party conversations, and if you are buying Gearbox’s newest title on Switch 2, you can play it with people on PlayStation, Xbox, and PC, and vice versa!

As Handsome Jack would say: “Butt Stallion says ‘Hello.” It’s not a relevant quote, but I love it.

Can You Play Borderlands 4 In Split-Screen?

Gearbox has confirmed that Borderlands 4 also has split-screen multiplayer, but it’s more limited compared to general crossplay.

All this information is via the Borderlands 4 FAQ. Under a section discussing the shooter’s co-op options, here’s what it says: “Borderlands 4 supports up to 4-player co-op online across all platforms, as well as 2-player splitscreen couch co-op on PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S.

To reiterate, split-screen gameplay is only available on PS5 and Xbox Series X|S.

You’re out of luck if you want to do this on the Nintendo Switch 2 or PC. The FAQ doesn’t explain why this is; the only thing we need to know is that this is the case. End of story. We can lock that answer up in the vault and move on.

Do We Know If Borderlands 4 Has Cross-Progression?

We unfortunately can’t say for certain if Borderlands 4 has cross-progression.

The FAQ covers a variety of topics in great detail. However, one aspect not covered is cross-progression: The ability to transfer your save file across different platforms. Free-to-play live-service games commonly have cross-progression, but for now, we’ll have to put a question mark next to this one until we get clarification.

Does Borderlands 4’s crossplay inclusions sell you on the game? Is the franchise the perfect multiplayer title? Let me know through the Insider Gaming forum. Also, tell us which new Vault Hunter you have your eyes on.

The complete Borderlands 4 trophy list, the game’s Roadmap, and its Xbox Game Pass status are other hot topics we’ve covered and answered for you.
